title: Cheaper financial advice could be offered to everyone
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Aug 3, 2015, 01:24 BST - UK Markets open in 6 hrs 36 mins Cheaper financial advice could be offered to everyone By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 23 minutes ago Print 
The government is worried that only rich people and pensioners have good access to advice right now 
Banks and investment firms could have to offer more financial advice for customers who are not rich enough to hire traditional financial advisors, as the result a Treasury review to be launched this Autumn. 
Free guidance is already on offer for pensioners who want to use their new-found freedom to consider investing in products other than annuities, following a change in the laws last year. 
And the Treasury and Financial Conduct Authority want to see how access to advice could be opened up across the market in savings, investments, mortgages and other areas. 
One option would be to give more resources and an increased remit to the Money Advice Service , which is funded by a levy on financial institutions but operates independently and gives out free advice. 
Regulators are also looking at simplified advice, where customers could enter details of their financial circumstances and investment objectives, and receive automated advice in return. 
The review will be chaired by Charles Roxburgh, Director General of Financial Services at the Treasury, and Tracey McDermott, who takes over as interim chief of the Financial Conduct Authority in September . 
“Ensuring that people have the appropriate information and advice in order to make important financial decisions is a priority for the FCA. Changes in the rules around mortgages and the introduction of the new pension freedoms mean that more people than ever before are looking for or are in need of financial advice,” said Ms McDermott. 
“The review is an opportunity to look at how the market is working right across the piece and has the potential to radically change the advice landscape to the benefit of both firms and consumers.” 
Tracy McDermott, who becomes interim chief of the Financial Conduct Authority next month, will co-chair the review 
One key problem in the market currently is that banks used to offer financial advice, but many exited the market when the Retail Distribution Review (RDR) rules came into force at the start of 2013. Advisors were told to charge customers a fee rather than commission, in a bid to remove the incentive to encourage customers to invest as much as possible in the highest-commission products. 
Advisors also had to be independent of any financial institution, meaning an advisor at one bank could have to recommend more products at a rival institution, making the process less attractive. In addition, the re-training costs were considered too high by some of the banks . 
The result is a substantial gap in the advice market. However, officials argue that there was a problem in the market long before the RDR changes, as advice was typically only sought by those with substantial wealth. 
As a result, the government is also keen to encourage more people with any level of financial resources to seek advice when making major decisions. 
“Making sure that our financial services sector supports working people at every stage of their lives is a key part of our long term plan,” said City Minister Harriett Baldwin. 
“That’s why we’ve launched a major new review to explore what more can be done to make sure consumers can access high quality and affordable advice so they can make informed decisions with their hard-earned money.”
